They can persist in the UI, or they can be dismissed by the user. Alert TypesIn the Appwrite console, we use two types of alerts: ClassTypealertInlineInline alerts present additional information to the user related to content within a form or a body of text.alert-stickyStickySticky alerts are used to notify the user about a change in the system status, or about a recently performed action. StatesIn the Appwrite console, we use five states of alerts: ClassType-DefaultUse this alert to provide general information to the user.is-infoInfoUse this alert to provide additional information or ‘tips’ to the user.is-successSuccessUse this alert to inform the user of a task that has been completed successfully.is-warningWarningUse this alert to warn the user that action may be required depending on the context.is-dangerDanger/ErrorUse this alert to warn the user about errors, and how they can fix the problem. to give the user enough information to help them understand the purpose of the alert and what needs to be done, if anything. Where necessary, a title can provide context. Alert messaging should be consistent across the application. Do Use human-readable language in your alerts to explain the purpose of the alert, and provide a Call to Action where necessary. Don't Show overly generic or patronizing messages in your alerts. 3.title: components - button
3.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components button Buttonsbutton Buttons are used to initialize an action. Button labels express what action will occur when the user interacts with it. TypesIn the Appwrite console, we use four types of buttons: ClassType-PrimaryWe recommend you use primary buttons for the principal call to action in a page or screen.is-secondarySecondarySecondary buttons can be used in conjunction with a primary button. As part of a pair with primary button, a secondary button will often perform a negative action, such as ‘Cancel’.is-textTextText buttons can be used to complete an action inside another component.is-only-iconIconIcon button with rounded corners Preview HTML Hello worldHello worldHello world Hello world Hello world Hello world "> <button class="button"> <span class="text">Hello world</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary"> <span class="text">Hello world</span> </button> <button class="button is-text"> <span class="text">Hello world</span> </button> <button class="button is-only-icon" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-plus" aria-hidden="true"> </span> </button> SizesThere are two sizes of buttons; large and medium. Each size has its own purpose, so make sure you use every size correctly. classType-MediumThe most commonly used size (default size). Our input fields also have a 40px height, which is why we use medium size next to input fields.is-bigLargeUse in a case of call to action that should stand out and have a lot of attention, mostly used on landing pages. Preview HTML Hello worldHello world Hello world Hello world"> <button class="button"> <span class="text">Hello world</span> </button> <button class="button is-big"> <span class="text">Hello world</span> </button> Buttons With IconsWe recommend using icons in cases where they have strong universal meaning and aid in the recognition of a button. In Appwrite, the icon is placed on the left by default. Preview HTML ButtonButtonButtonButtonButtonButtonButtonButton Button Button Button Button Button Button Button Button"> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-plus" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-cheveron-left" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="text">Button</span> <span class="icon-cheveron-right" aria-hidden="true"> </span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-trash" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-duplicate" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-download" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-link" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> <button class="button is-secondary" aria-label="Add new item"> <span class="icon-external-link" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">Button</span> </button> Buttons List Preview HTML Button 1Button 2Button 3Button 4 Button 1 Button 2 Button 3 Button 4 "> <ul class="buttons-list"> <li class="buttons-list-item"> <button class="button is-text"> <span class="text">Button 1</span> </button> </li> <li class="buttons-list-item"> <button class="button is-text"> <span class="text">Button 2</span> </button> </li> <li class="buttons-list-item"> <button class="button is-text"> <span class="text">Button 3</span> </button> </li> <li class="buttons-list-item"> <button class="button is-text"> <span class="text">Button 4</span> </button> </li> </ul> UsageTips to keep in mind to increase consistency and readability in buttons: Do Increase recognition by using icons with universal meaning. Increase readability by keeping text short and using uppercase letter only for the first word. Don't Avoid using specific icons, uppercase in every word and long sentences. box card

4.title: components - card
4.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components card Cardscard Cards are used to group related content in a single container. This can include text, images, lists, buttons, and other elements. StylesIn the Appwrite console, we use two styles of cards borders: ClassType-SolidSolid border should be use in all cards.is-border-dashedDashedWe recommend you use dash border for empty state cards. Preview HTML "> <article class="card" style="width: 300px; height: 100px;"> </article> <article class="card is-border-dashed" style="width: 300px; height: 100px;"> </article> PaddingWe recommend card paddings should be equal on all sides. For example, in the Appwrite console we use 32px.You can change the card padding by setting the --card-padding CSS variable. Preview HTML "> <article class="card u-grid" style="width: 300px; height: 200px; --card-padding: 64px; --card-bg-color: var(--color-information-200);"> <div style="background-color: hsl(var(--color-neutral-300))"> </div> </article> <article class="card u-grid" style="width: 300px; height: 200px; --card-padding: 16px; --card-bg-color: var(--color-information-200);"> <div style="background-color: hsl(var(--color-neutral-300))"> </div> </article> UsageIn Appwrite we are using cards to show empty states, to update / delete objects, to display overview, etc. A card can include avatars, buttons, illustrations, lists, tags and text for example: Create your first file to get started.Need a hand? Check out our documentation.DocumentationCreate file button code panel

Modals require direct interaction in order to be dismissed. ComponentsModals consist of five components: ClassTypemodal-formFormmodal-headerHeadermodal-titleTitlemodal-contentContentmodal-footerFooter Preview HTML Open Modal e.stopPropagation()">Modal titleModal label text.CancelCreate Open Modal e.stopPropagation()"> Modal title Modal label text. 16.title: components - selectors
16.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components selectors Selectors Choice selectors allow users to complete tasks which involve making choices such as selecting options, switching settings on or off, or adding or removing items. VariantsIn the Appwrite console, we use three variants of choice selectors. ClassTypeDescription-CheckboxCheckboxes allow users to select one or more items from a set.switchCheckboxSwitches are used to quickly toggle between two possible states. They are commonly used for “on/off” switches.-RadioRadio buttons allow users to select one item from a set. CheckboxCheckboxes allow users to select one or more items from a set. Preview HTML "> <input type="checkbox"/> <input type="checkbox" checked="true"/> States AttributeTypeDescriptiondisabledDisabledShown when clicking on a selector is not allowed. Preview HTML "> <input type="checkbox" disabled/> <input type="checkbox" checked="true" disabled/> SizesThere are three sizes of selectors; large, medium and small. Each size has its own purpose, so make sure you use every size correctly. classTypeDescriptionis-smallSmall-Mediumis-largeLarge Preview HTML "> <div class="u-flex u-flex-vertical u-gap-16 "> <div class="u-flex u-gap-16 u-main-center u-cross-center"> <input type="checkbox" class="is-small"/> <input type="checkbox" checked="true"/> <input type="checkbox" class="is-large"/> </div> </div> SwitchSwitches are used to quickly toggle between two possible states. They are commonly used for “on/off” switches. Preview HTML "> <div class="u-flex u-gap-16 u-main-center u-cross-center"> <input type="checkbox" class="switch"/> <input type="checkbox" class="switch" checked="true"/> </div> States AttributeTypeDescriptiondisabledDisabledShown when clicking on a selector is not allowed. Preview HTML "> <div class="u-flex u-gap-16 u-main-center u-cross-center"> <input type="checkbox" class="switch" disabled/> <input type="checkbox" class="switch" checked="true" disabled/> </div> SizesThere are three sizes of selectors; large, medium and small. Each size has its own purpose, so make sure you use every size correctly. classTypeDescriptionis-smallSmall-Mediumis-largeLarge Preview HTML "> <div class="u-flex u-gap-16 u-main-center u-cross-center"> <input type="checkbox" class="switch is-small"/> <input type="checkbox" class="switch" checked="true"/> <input type="checkbox" class="switch is-large"/> </div> RadioRadio buttons allow users to select one item from a set. Preview HTML "> <input type="radio" name="radio-1"/> <input type="radio" name="radio-1" checked="true"/> States AttributeTypeDescriptiondisabledDisabledShown when clicking on a selector is not allowed. Preview HTML "> <input type="radio" name="radio-2" disabled/> <input type="radio" name="radio-2" checked="true" disabled/> SizeThere are three sizes of selectors; large, medium and small. Each size has its own purpose, so make sure you use every size correctly. classTypeDescriptionis-smallSmall-Mediumis-largeLarge Preview HTML "> <div class="u-flex u-gap-16 u-main-center u-cross-center"> <input type="radio" class="is-small" name="size"/> <input type="radio" name="size" checked="true"/> <input type="radio" class="is-large" name="size"/> </div> UsageWe recommend choice selectors next to labels should have at minimum 8px of space in between for legibility. Choice selectors should be aligned to the center of a single line of text. If there are multiple lines in a label should be aligned to the center of the first line in the label.Checkboxes allow users to select multiple items from a set. Do Use checkboxes to allow users select one or more options from a list with related items. Don't Do not use switches, they don’t imply the items are related, and take up more visual space. Switches and radio buttons refer to a single item. Radio buttons allow selecting onlyone item from a list, while switches allow turning an item on or off. Do If each item in a set can be independently controlled, use switches to allow on or off options. Don't Do not use radio buttons to allow on or off options. output status

19.title: components - tabs
19.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components tabs Tabstabs Tab navigation allows users to switch between multiple sections of content within a single screen. ComponentsTabs consist of four components: ClassTypetabs-listList-tabs-itemItem-tabs-buttonButton-tabs-button-scrollScrollUsed when there is not enough space to display all tabs, mostly on mobile devices. The tabs-button-scroll element can be hidden by adding u-hide class to it. Preview HTML OverviewSessionsActivitySettings Overview Sessions Activity Settings "> <div class="tabs" style="width: 350px"> <button class="tabs-button-scroll is-start" aria-label="Show items in start side"> <span class="icon-cheveron-left" aria-hidden="true"> </span> </button> <button class="tabs-button-scroll is-end" aria-label="Show items in end side"> <span class="icon-cheveron-right" aria-hidden="true"> </span> </button> <ul class="tabs-list"> <li class="tabs-item"> <a class="tabs-button is-selected" href="#"> <span class="text">Overview</span> </a> </li> <li class="tabs-item"> <a class="tabs-button" href="#"> <span class="text">Sessions</span> </a> </li> <li class="tabs-item"> <a class="tabs-button" href="#"> <span class="text">Activity</span> </a> </li> <li class="tabs-item"> <a class="tabs-button" href="#"> <span class="text">Settings</span> </a> </li> </ul> </div> UsageIn most scenarios, you should use no more than six tabs. This maintains an uncluttered UI and reduces cognitive load for users.If more than six tabs are needed, and you can’t use another patterns in order to keep consistency, we recommend that you add a horizontal scrolling element to the tab navigation.The right arrow should always be visible. If the user can scroll right, the arrow is active, otherwise the arrow should be disabled. The left arrow should only visible if the user can scroll left. tables tags

20.title: components - tags
20.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile components tags Tagstag Tags help organize and differentiate between different categories of content. In the Appwrite console, tags may be interactive or static (informative). InformativeInformative tags are used to visually label information for easy understanding and/or navigation. In the Appwrite console, we use our system colours for each type of tag (gray, blue, green, orange, red) depending on context. ClassType-DefaultUse this tag to provide general details to the user. In the Appwrite console this style is typically used for ‘disabled’ state tags.is-infoInfoUse this tag to provide additional information or ‘tips’ to the user.is-successSuccessUse this tag to inform the user of a task that has been completed or verified successfully.is-warningWarningUse this tag to warn the user that action may be required, or a task is currently processing, depending on the context.is-dangerDanger / ErrorUse this tag to warn the user about an error that may have occured or a task that failed. Preview HTML defaultinfosuccesswarningerror default info success warning error"> <div class="tag"> <span class="icon-info" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">default</span> </div> <div class="tag is-info"> <span class="icon-info" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">info</span> </div> <div class="tag is-success"> <span class="icon-check-circle" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">success</span> </div> <div class="tag is-warning"> <span class="icon-exclamation" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">warning</span> </div> <div class="tag is-danger"> <span class="icon-exclamation-circle" aria-hidden="true"> </span> <span class="text">error</span> </div> UsageWe recommend the use of icons within informative tags only when necessary to convey context. Do Keep tag text short and simple so as not to distract the user who may be scanning for information. Don't If you choose to use icons, don’t mix and match their placement. InteractiveClickable or tappable tags. In the Appwrite console these are typically used to allow users to copy or edit an element’s ID. Use an icon to clarify the action (e.g. the ‘duplicate’ icon for copy and ‘pencil’ icon for edit). 24.title: foundations - border-radius
24.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations border radius Border Radius Different sizes of border radius are used throughout the Appwrite UI according to the component size. SizesIn Appwrite console we use 4 sizes of border radius: VariableValue--border-radius-xsmall4pxDesigned to soften the corners of small components, such as checkboxes, input fields, buttons, alerts and tooltips. Preview HTML "> <div class="card" style="border-radius: var(--border-radius-xsmall); width: 200px; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;"> </div> VariableValue--border-radius-small8pxDesigned to soften the corners of small components that are part of a bigger one or for medium components, such as items in the sidebar menu and popovers. Preview HTML "> <div class="card" style="border-radius: var(--border-radius-small); width: 200px; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;"> </div> VariableValue--border-radius-medium16pxUsed when a UI element is large or needs to float above the underlying UI, such as cards, modals and tables. Preview HTML "> <div class="card" style="border-radius: var(--border-radius-medium); width: 200px; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;"> </div> VariableValue--border-radius-circular50%Used only on specific elements that needs to be rounded, such as icon buttons, avatars, tags and switches. Preview HTML "> <div class="card" style="border-radius: var(--border-radius-circular); width: 200px; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;"> </div> Usage Do Use large corner radius for big surface. Don't Use small corner radius for big surface, it will make it look really sharp and serious. user profile colors

25.title: foundations - colors

All shades we are using were selected while maintaining AA accessibility level. BrandOur expanded brand color palette contains 3 shades. This is our primary color palette used for primary actions. --color-primary-100--color-primary-200--color-primary-300 NeutralsWe are using our neutral palette for both light and dark modes. Neutrals used mostly for backgrounds, text, separators etc. --color-neutral-0--color-neutral-5--color-neutral-10--color-neutral-30--color-neutral-50--color-neutral-70--color-neutral-100--color-neutral-120--color-neutral-150--color-neutral-200--color-neutral-300--color-neutral-400--color-neutral-500 System ColorsIn the Appwrite console, we use 4 system colors: TypeInformationBlue often used for informative alerts and ‘selected’ mode in choice selectors.SuccessGreen often used for success alerts.WarningOrange often used for warning alerts and modals.ErrorRed often used for danger/error alerts. Information--color-information-10--color-information-50--color-information-100--color-information-120--color-information-200Success--color-success-10--color-success-50--color-success-100--color-success-120--color-success-200Warning--color-warning-10--color-warning-50--color-warning-100--color-warning-120--color-warning-200Danger--color-danger-10--color-danger-50--color-danger-100--color-danger-120--color-danger-200 Additional ColorsIn the Appwrite console, we use the colors below in specific components, such as avatars. 26.title: foundations - elevation
26.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations elevation Elevation Elevation is the relative distance between two surfaces along the z-axis. Shadows and blurs create a layered effect that visually indicates that an object is “elevated” in priority or hierarchy. TypesIn the Appwrite console we use two types of elevation: ClassTypeshadow-smallSmallUse to show contrast between layout elements, such as cards or tables, to the surface.shadow-largeLargeUse to show contrast between ‘floating’ components, such as popovers, alerts or modals, to the surface below. Preview HTML shadow-smallshadow-large shadow-small shadow-large"> <div class="card" style="box-shadow:var(--shadow-small);"> <p class="text">shadow-small</p> </div> <div class="card" style="box-shadow:var(--shadow-large);"> <p class="text">shadow-large</p> </div> UsageSmall shadows should be used with standard layout components (e.g. cards, tables).We recommend the use of a large drop-shadow for floating components (e.g. popovers, alerts, modals). Do To create contrast between a floating surface and the surface beneath, use shadow-large. Don't Do not make floating elements look flat by not using shadows. colors icons

27.title: foundations - icons
27.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations icons Icons An icon is a visual representation of a command, device, directory, or common action.In Appwrite we use heroicons solid icons library. Werecommend the use of up to three icon sizes for consistency. In the Appwriteconsole, for example, icons are either 24px, 20px (the default), or 16px. Iconsize should depend on the height of the label the icon is next to, or if it’snext to a label at all. UsageWe recommend icons next to labels should have at minimum 4px of space inbetween for legibility. Icons should be aligned to the center of a single lineof text. If there are multiple lines in a label should be aligned to thecenter of the first line in the label. Do Use minimum 4px of space between icon to text and make sure they are centered. Don't Do not use less than 4px of space. If there are multiple lines in a label, do not center the icon to all of them, but to the first line. elevation typography

28.title: foundations - typography
28.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile foundations typography Typography Typography is a system of fonts used to provide a clear hierarchy, organize information, and to assist users during the product journey. ScaleWe use a font scale to determine the size of the typography. The font sizesfit well with with the 4px grid. The sizes are not directly matched with HTMLtags, in order to perserve semantics. Preview HTML Heading level 1Heading level 2Heading level 3Heading level 4Heading level 5Heading level 6Heading level 7 Heading level 1 Heading level 2 Heading level 3 Heading level 4 Heading level 5 Heading level 6 Heading level 7"> <div class="u-flex u-flex-vertical u-cross-start u-gap-24"> <h1 class="heading-level-1">Heading level 1</h1> <h2 class="heading-level-2">Heading level 2</h2> <h3 class="heading-level-3">Heading level 3</h3> <h4 class="heading-level-4">Heading level 4</h4> <h5 class="heading-level-5">Heading level 5</h5> <h6 class="heading-level-6">Heading level 6</h6> <h6 class="heading-level-7">Heading level 7</h6> </div> Preview HTML EYEBROW HEADING level 1EYEBROW HEADING level 2EYEBROW HEADING level 3 EYEBROW HEADING level 1 EYEBROW HEADING level 2 EYEBROW HEADING level 3"> <div class="u-grid u-gap-24"> <h4 class="eyebrow-heading-1">EYEBROW HEADING level 1</h4> <h5 class="eyebrow-heading-2">EYEBROW HEADING level 2</h5> <h6 class="eyebrow-heading-3">EYEBROW HEADING level 3</h6> </div> Preview HTML Body text level 1 SemiBoldBody text level 1 RegularBody text level 1 UnderlineBody text level 2 SemiBoldBody text level 2 RegularBody text level 2 Underline Body text level 1 SemiBold Body text level 1 Regular Body text level 1 Underline Body text level 2 SemiBold Body text level 2 Regular Body text level 2 Underline"> <div class="u-grid u-gap-24"> <p class="u-bold">Body text level 1 SemiBold</p> <p>Body text level 1 Regular</p> <p style="text-decoration: underline">Body text level 1 Underline</p> <p class="u-bold">Body text level 2 SemiBold</p> <p>Body text level 2 Regular</p> <p style="text-decoration: underline">Body text level 2 Underline</p> </div> Preview HTML Code level 1 Code level 1"> <div class="u-grid u-gap-24"> <code class="inline-code">Code level 1</code> </div> UsageEyebrow headings can be used to compliment headings or for subtleheaders for lists.We recommend the use of the Underline text style for inline links. Do Use Underline text style for inline links as it guarantees link visibility when scanning text. Don't Use the Underline text style for text that is not linked. Underlines provide a strong perceived affordance of clickability, and users will be confused if underlined text doesn’t match this perception. icons container

29.title: getting-started
29.content: GitHub GitHub Home Getting Started Foundations border radius colors elevation icons typography Utility box model colors display position reset responsive text theme visibility Layout container navigation pagination Components alerts avatar box button card code panel collapsible drop list drop tabs file preview grid item input fields list loader modal output selectors status tables tabs tags tooltip uploader user profile getting started Getting Started Pink Design, is the Appwrite open-source design system for building consistent and reusable user interfaces. To learn how to use the library, follow the steps below. CSS FileBefore we StartMake sure you have a project set up where you want to use the CSS library.Include the CSS library in your projectcopy the next code to the <head> section of your HTML file."> <link rel="stylesheet" href="path/to/css/library.css">Once you have included the CSS library in your project, you can start using its styles in your HTML elements. JavascriptBefore we StartMake sure you have npm installed on your computer. If you don’t have italready, you can download and install it from the npm website.Initialize your projectNavigate to your project directory in your terminal or command prompt. Inthe project directory, paste the next command. npm initCreate a json fileCreate a package.json file. This file will store information about yourproject, including the dependencies you install.Install the CSS libraryAfter initializing your project, copy the next command to install the CSS library. npm install @aw-labs/uiInclude the library in your projectAfter downloading the library, it should be added to your project’s node_modules directory. Now you can include the library in your project by importing it in your JavaScript files. import "@aw-labs/ui/dist/pinkui.css";Alternatively, you can add a link to the CSS file in the <head> section of your HTML file, similar to how you would do it without using npm:"> <link rel="stylesheet" href="node_modules/@aw-labs/ui/dist/pinkui.css">
